newsitem.title: GERMANY: Bonn farm ministry sees slow EU grain stocks rise.
newsitem.headline: Bonn farm ministry sees slow EU grain stocks rise.

text.p: A Bonn farm ministry official said on Wednesday the European Union would start to rebuild its empty grain stocks from the 1997 harvest onwards, if not earlier.
EU stocks in mid-August were just 2.2 million tonnes of which Germany held two million, Ralf Kosmetschke of the ministry's grain department said at a harvest conference in Hamburg.
A planned barley export allocation for Saudi Arabia, mostly from intervention, would further squeeze public stocks, which had fallen amid farm reform efforts and buoyant world demand.
EU grain harvests this year were estimated at 186-190 million tonnes, up 10-13 million from last year.
This would be absorbed by domestic demand and a higher rate of exports, depending on Commission policy in the 1996/97 season.
Kosmetschke said any intervention stockbuilding would be "moderate, perhaps in a 1.5-3.0 million tonne range".
He expected the Commission to continue to put pressure on internal grain prices to safeguard consumer interests.
But a halving of land set-aside to five percent for the 1997 harvest could result in a 193-195 million tonne crop.
"Some 33-35 million tonnes of that crop would remain for subsidised exports and stockbuilding," Kosmetschke said.
He based this estimate on seven million tonnes of envisaged imports and domestic use of 167 million tonnes.
Apart from marketable grain reserves, EU states might also wish to rebuild strategic stocks for emergencies, he said.
Bonn had already decided on such a strategy over the next 10 years, but details were not yet available.
The process would be slow because of tight budgets and high grain prices.
